Cooper Farms, Van Wert, OH is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68.  In addition to other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.



Our goal is to promote overall worker, public, and plant safety.



Cooper Farms, Van Wert, OH. located at 6793 U.S. Rt. 127 North, Van Wert, Ohio.  We manufacture some of the finest turkey products in the world.  The facility includes processing tanks, piping, packaging equipment, raw materials warehousing, finished goods refrigerated storage, an Ammonia refrigeration engine room, boilers, and miscellaneous utilities. 



The refrigeration system required for our production process necessitates the submission of this Risk Management Plan.  The refrigeration system contains anhydrous ammonia in a quantity greater than the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds outlined in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program regulations.



Cooper Farms has implemented numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia as well as other hazardous substances, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid property damage.



Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved as necessary. 



Cooper Farms has organized the information and polices pertaining to the process into a complete library consisting of five numbere

d volumes, as well as reference materials. Volume numbers are assigned to sets of reference manuals, such as the Operation and Maintenance manuals. The library also incorporates the use of video tapes and computerized tests.



VOLUME I of the PSM/RMP Library incorporates mainly policies. The following policies are included in Volume I:



Employee Participation Guidelines: This policy outlines the commitment between management and employees to establish a program for a successful (safe) program.



Process Safety Information: This includes information on the ammonia inventory at the facility, applicable codes, design standards, and information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia (referenced from the IIAR Ammonia Data Book).



Process Hazard Analysis Program: This program outlines a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving potentially hazardous chemicals such as Ammonia.



Contractor Qualification Guidelines: This guideline has been established to verify that the contractors working in the facility are qualified to work on the system, trained in the hazards associated with their work, and made aware of the hazards presented by the facility to the employees of the contractor.



Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs: These programs have been developed to monitor and provide a "checks and balances" system to monitor changes in the facility and to verify that changes are safe and consistent with company policy.



Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, Employee training, etc..) have been developed. For information specific to these consult the Safety Manager.



VOLUME II incorporates information on the specific system components of the production area equipment. This information is used as a reference source for the operator to positively identify system components. This manual also provides a checklist for per

forming the yearly Mechanical Integrity Inspection.



VOULME III incorporates a complete valve list, process and instrumentation diagrams, flow schematics, and other drawings pertinent to the refrigeration equipment. The valve list contains information on the type, port , identifying number, use, location, model, manufacturer, drawing reference, and normal operating position of each valve in the system. Process and Instrumentation Diagrams are included for the individual refrigeration system components. Flow schematics are included showing the entire refrigeration system. A Block flow diagram provides a brief overview of the system. Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions. Plan views are included to allow the operator to physically locate refrigeration equipment in the building.



VOULME IV incorporates a complete set of standard operating procedures for the production area equipment. Describing the proper steps for preparing components for start-up, starting components, monitoring normal operation, shutting down as part of normal operation, restarting equipment as part of normal operation, shutting down equipment for maintenance, restarting equipment after maintenance, shutting down equipment in emergency situations, restarting equipment after an emergency situations shutdown, and pump out procedures. Also included as a part of each Standard Operating Procedure is the Technical Operating Specifications for the associated system components. This information includes consequences of deviation from standard operating procedures.



VOULME V contains Operation and Maintenance Information for the refrigeration equipment including manufactures information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventative maintenance procedures.



Cooper Farms also incorporates additional safety items such as tagging of all ammonia system valves and components. 



DESCRIPTION OF THE REFRIGERATION SYSTEM



Cooper Farms, Van Wert, OH. is a poultry b

ased processing and distribution facility. The facility incorporates a standard evaporation and compression closed loop ammonia refrigeration system. The systems is installed to operate as a two-temperature single stage system. The compressors are split as High Stage and Low Stage Compressors. There exists, two different levels of saturated suction temperatures. Each level of suction temperature services a specific area of the plant. 





SUMMARY OF THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Cooper Farms has had no accident(s) in the past five years involving ammonia.





DESCRIPTION OF THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



In the event that an ammonia leak is detected employees are to notify a member of management , who will immediately contact the Emergency Response Coordinator (ERC).

In the event that the ERC is unreachable, an Alternate should be contacted. The ERC or Alternate has complete authority to commit all available resources in the event of an emergency. In the event that none of the listed personnel are on-site, the senior management person shall direct operations until the ERC or Alternate arrives on-site. 



The ERC and alternates are responsible for emergency response coordination with state and local agencies on a 24-hour basis.  Upon notification of an existing, or imminent emergency situation, the ERC will immediately identify the character, exact source, amount and extent (area) of the emergency.



The ERC will assess possible hazards both direct and indirect to human health, the environment and/or property both inside and outside of the plant.  After this information is received, a decision is made whether or not to implement the provisions of the Emergency Action Plan.



Upon enactment of the Emergency Action Plan, the ERC will be responsible for:



Determination of the need for a plant evacuation, or Sheltering in Place;



Notification of appropriate governmental agencies and off-site responders; 



Notification of appropriate corporate personnel.

Documentation during and reporting after an emergency situation.



Once the Incident Commander arrives on scene, a report is given and the Off-site Incident Commander takes control of the situation.



Cooper Farms is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of Cooper Farms to remain an industry leader. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system.



We have recently added an additional team member with the primary responsibility of over seeing PSM and RMP activities.



In February of 2012, we finishd the installation of two 1.5 megawatt wind turbines which will provide over 50% of the Facility's power needs, while saving vital natural resources.



In addition we are implementing many "green" practices. Including:



- Recycling of plastic cooking pans to a local drainage time manufacturer.



- Reusing plastic cooking pans numerous times instead of disposing of them after a single use. We have installed an industrial pan washer to clean the used p[ans.



- Soy oil is used for browning of the cooked meats. The used oil can then be used for heating at local hatcheries.



- We are in the final construction phases of a disolved air filtration floation system. This will remove the cooking solids from the final treatment process.



In the near future we hope to further expand our facility and processes.
